section.title: Reading
section.p: Read Sections 3.6 and 3.7 of Applied Discrete Structures. It is only necessary to read 3.6 through Example 3.6.7.

Response question: You don’t need induction to prove that the sum of the first n Positive integers equals \frac{n(n+1)}{2}. Google “Gauss sum of consecutive integers” and read about how you can do it even more simply. Explain what you read.

Also, turn in solutions to these exercises:
Simplify the expressions
(\sum_{k=1}^{n+1}k^2) -(\sum_{k=1}^n k^2)
\sum_{k=1}^n (\frac{1}{k}-\frac{1}{k+1})
\frac{(n+2)!}{n!}
Prove that for n \ge 0, \sum_{k=0}^n {2^k} = 2^{n+1}-1.

li.p: Prove that it is possible to make up any postage of 28 cents or more using only five-cent and eight-cent stamps.
Suppose that a particular real number x has the property that x + \frac{1}{x} is an integer. Prove that x^n + \frac{1}{x^n} is an integer for all natural numbers n.
